Question for anyone who was around at the time: what was the point of making `Array` require `undef`? Is it just intended as a reminder to the user that the array will be full of undefined values upon allocation? IIRC we didn’t used to require it..

I’m not sure if it’s because of the `undef` or just the need to declare the type, but one way or another the students in my intro class always seem to want to use (e.g.) `ones` or `zeros` or `fill` instead because they can’t be bothered to remember the proper syntax for `Array`…

text: I think the idea was partially to make it more explicit that you're requesting uninitialized memory and partially to free up methods for something or other.

text: At first it was `Array{T}(uninitialized, dims...)`, which is much, _much_ worse than `undef`. :grimacing: I think that was changed because it was a bit too cumbersome to write.
